questions.text: Umesh, a 35-year-old male, presents to the outpatient department of Dr Mehta’s Hospitals, Chennai with intermittent fever, chills, and sweating for the past 10 days. He had recently returned from a 2-week trip to the Sundarbans, a forested region known for its endemicity with malaria. Laboratory investigations confirm the diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum malaria, which is sensitive to chloroquine. Dr Dileep Kumar, the treating physician is planning to ensure a radical cure to prevent future relapses. Which of the following is the drug of choice for radical cure of malaria in this patient?

During your rural posting after the internship, you encounter a patient of acute cardiac failure. Your preferred drug for this condition is dobutamine. However, it is not available there. Which of the following other drugs, or combination of drugs, would be a suitable alternative, giving the pharmacologic equivalent of what you want the dobutamine to do?

Dr. Apurv Mehra is managing a 45-year-old patient named Rakesh, who presents with recurring episodes of joint pain and inflammation. After a thorough assessment, Dr. Mehra diagnoses him with hyperuricemia predisposing to gout. To better understand the patient's uric acid metabolism, the doctor decides to measure the total amount of uric acid. After receiving the baseline measurements, Rakesh is prescribed an "antigout" medication. Several weeks into the therapy, Dr. Mehra repeats the 24-hour urine uric acid measurement to evaluate the drug's effectiveness. He observes a significant reduction in the urate content in the post-treatment sample. Throughout the treatment period, Rakesh confirms no new health concerns, and he assures Dr. Mehra that his daily proteins and purine intake remains unchanged. Given these observations, which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to Rakesh?

A 5-year-old male child presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of recurrent headaches, vomiting. Parents report that the headaches have been progressively worsening over the past few weeks, and the vomiting episodes are occurring almost daily. They are also concerned about the child's developmental delay, noting a significant loss of previously acquired skills such as speaking in full sentences and walking steadily. On physical examination, the child's head circumference is noted to be above the 97th percentile for his age, with a tense and bulging anterior fontanelle. The child exhibits the "sunsetting" sign, where the sclera is visible above the irises when looking downward. Additionally, he has an unsteady gait and difficulty walking without support. MRI is shown here. What is the likely cause of hydrocephalus?

A 37-year-old female with a medical history significant for hypertension and seizure disorder has been undergoing treatment for major depressive disorder. She was initially prescribed fluoxetine, which resulted in significant clinical improvement in her depressive symptoms. However, she now reports experiencing bothersome sexual side effects, specifically a marked decrease in libido. The psychiatrist considers switching her medication. Which of the following is the best advise for the patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Should not change the antidepressant as initial response is good

questions.text: In the realm of medical practice, the principle of vicarious liability plays a crucial role in determining legal responsibility. Which of the following statements best exemplifies the concept of vicarious liability in cases of medical negligence?

options.label: A
options.text: Medical institutions can only be held responsible for the actions of their employed medical professionals if institution had direct knowledge of the negligence.

options.label: B
options.text: Vicarious liability does not apply when medical professionals commit gross negligence, as such actions are considered beyond the scope of their employment.

options.label: C
options.text: Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution

options.label: D
options.text: Vicarious liability mandates that medical institutions are immune to legal action if the medical professional involved had a valid license to practice.

questions.correct_answer: C. Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution

questions.text: You are assisting the gynaecologist in a total laparoscopic hysterectomy for a 45year old woman with multiple uterine fibroids. The uterus is about 18 weeks size of a gravid uterus, and you wonder how the gynaecologist will manage to take the entire uterus out once the hysterectomy is complete. Which of the following is not a technique of specimen removal following a laparoscopic hysterectomy?

options.label: A
options.text: In bag laparoscopic morcellation of the specimen

questions.correct_answer: D. Laser fulguration of the specimen
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Laser fulguration of the specimen

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient undergoing orthopedic surgery for a femur fracture starts to develop tachycardia and hypercarbia. The anesthesiologist initiates treatment with dantrolene. Genetic testing is recommended to identify the genetic basis of this disease in the patient. Which of the following chromosomes is responsible for this disease?

A 7-year-old child is brought to the dentist by their parents due to facial swelling, which has been progressively increasing over the past year. The swelling is bilateral and involves the lower jaw. On examination, there is no pain or tenderness associated with the swelling. Dental radiographs are shown here. The child's dental development is otherwise normal. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and radiographic findings?

A 54-year-old woman from a rural area presented to a local practitioner with a 3-day history of cough and fever. She had been taking diclofenac twice daily for osteoarthritis. The practitioner prescribed moxifloxacin, assuming an upper respiratory tract infection. Although her symptoms of fever and cough improved, on the third day of treatment, she experienced a generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS). The same practitioner diagnosed her with grand mal epilepsy and advised her to start valproate for 3 years. After taking first dose of valproate she developed vomiting and gastric upset. Worried, she contacted her son, a medical student at MAMC, Delhi. He recalled a lecture by Dr. GOGA and persuaded her to seek a second opinion. Comprehensive evaluations at MAMC, including a CT scan and EEG, showed no abnormalities. What should be the immediate step in her management?

options.label: A
options.text: Discontinue valproate immediately and advise her to avoid concurrent use of NSAIDs and fluoroquinolones in the future

options.label: B
options.text: Taper off valproate over a week and introduce a different AED for long-term management

options.label: C
options.text: Continue valproate, but switch her osteoarthritis medication from diclofenac to paracetamol

options.label: D
options.text: Restart moxifloxacin under observation to confirm if it was indeed the causative factor for the seizure.

questions.correct_answer: A. Discontinue valproate immediately and advise her to avoid concurrent use of NSAIDs and fluoroquinolones in the future
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Discontinue valproate immediately and advise her to avoid concurrent use of NSAIDs and fluoroquinolones in the future.

Explanation:

  • • The interaction between diclofenac (an NSAID) and moxifloxacin (a fluoroquinolone) has the potential to lower the seizure threshold, which is the probable cause for her GTCS episode. As all other investigations (like the CT scan and EEG) did not reveal any inherent pathology and considering her recent medication history, the seizure is most likely a result of the drug interaction. Moreover, the immediate adverse reactions to valproate further suggest it's not suitable for her. Thus, the logical step would be to discontinue valproate and ensure she avoids such drug combinations in the future.
  • • The interaction between diclofenac (an NSAID) and moxifloxacin (a fluoroquinolone) has the potential to lower the seizure threshold, which is the probable cause for her GTCS episode.
  • • diclofenac
  • • moxifloxacin
  • • As all other investigations (like the CT scan and EEG) did not reveal any inherent pathology and considering her recent medication history, the seizure is most likely a result of the drug interaction. Moreover, the immediate adverse reactions to valproate further suggest it's not suitable for her. Thus, the logical step would be to discontinue valproate and ensure she avoids such drug combinations in the future.

questions.text: A 15y girl is brought by her mother to the OPD. She says that her daughter has not yet attained menarche. She has been doing well in school and is on the school basketball team. However, her mother has noticed her voice has deepened and there is coarse hair growth on the chin since a few months. When you examine her, you find there is no breast development. There is sparse pubic and axillary hair and on local examination you find there is an enlarged clitoris. A karyotype done, reveals 46XY and an ultrasound reveals an absent uterus. Which is the most likely possibility?

A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a recent road traffic accident. He was involved in a high-speed collision and sustained blunt trauma to his abdomen and lower back. He complains of severe left-sided flank pain and haematuria. This was managed conservatively in view of AAST Grade 2 injury on CECT. During his in-patient stay, it was noticed that his BP is increasing while he was previously normotensive. His Baseline CECT is shown here. What is the likely explanation for his course?

A person is found dead in his home. He was living alone. Neighbours called the police when they experienced a foul smell from home. As told by neighbours, the deceased person didn’t interact much with others and was a very quiet person. The dead body was brought for postmortem examination, and following injuries were seen as shown below: Based on above context which statement is true?

A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency room with complaints of severe headaches and visual disturbances for the past week. She describes the headaches as throbbing in nature, located mainly around her temples and forehead. The visual disturbances include blurred vision and seeing "flashing lights" in her peripheral vision. She has no significant medical history but mentions that her brother has a history of similar symptoms. On detailed neurological examination reveals bilateral papilledema on fundoscopic examination. Further evaluation, including neuroimaging, confirms the presence of an intracranial mass. The radiologist takes measurements and identifies the location of the mass relative to the patient's skull using a reference point known as Frankfurt's plane. This plane passes through?

options.label: A
options.text: Supraorbital margin and upper margin of external acoustic meatus

options.label: B
options.text: Supraorbital margin and lower margin of external acoustic meatus

options.label: C
options.text: Infraorbital margin and upper margin of external acoustic meatus

options.label: D
options.text: Infraorbital margin and lower margin of external acoustic meatus

questions.correct_answer: C. Infraorbital margin and upper margin of external acoustic meatus
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Infraorbital margin and upper margin of external acoustic meatus

questions.text: Correct statement about Population (age-sex) Pyramid is:

options.label: A
options.text: Developing countries pyramid shows low young age dependency due to lesser fertility

options.label: B
options.text: Developed countries pyramid shows inverted triangle due to large number of geriatric population

options.label: C
options.text: Developing countries pyramid is asymmetric indicative of unfavourable sex ratio

options.label: D
options.text: Developed countries pyramid span is higher indicating lower life expectancy

questions.correct_answer: C. Developing countries pyramid is asymmetric indicative of unfavourable sex ratio
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Developing countries pyramid is asymmetric indicative of unfavourable sex ratio

questions.text: Chetan, a patient in the emergency department, presents with severe drug-induced hypotension, registering a blood pressure of 75/50 mmHg. Over the years, you have managed acute hypotension from various causes using an intravenous injection of x mg of methoxamine. Given Chetan's medical history of taking his current medication for several months, and considering he shows no signs of volume depletion or hemorrhage, you administer the standard dose of methoxamine. Surprisingly, Chetan's response is unexpected and intense, causing his blood pressure to soar to 180/110 mmHg. Given this stark elevation in blood pressure post-administration, which of the following medications did Chetan most likely overdose on?

A 55-year-old woman is evaluated for a 4-day history of chest pain and cough productive of green sputum. Medical history is significant for heart failure and coronary artery disease. She has not recently taken antibiotics or been hospitalized. Medications are furosemide, lisinopril, metoprolol, and aspirin. On physical examination, temperature is 38.1 °C (100.6 °F) and pulse rate is 96/min; blood pressure and respiration rate are normal. Oxygen saturation is 94% breathing ambient air. Crackles are heard at the left lung base. Rapid influenza molecular assay is positive for influenza A. COVID-19 testing is negative. A chest radiograph shows left lower lobe consolidation. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

A 65-year-old man with history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with right leg swelling and pain. The patient denies trauma to the leg and reports it was normal yesterday. Examination of the right lower extremity is significant for extreme tenderness to palpation, erythema, and edema extending up to the knee. X-ray of the right leg shows tissue swelling without gas or osteomyelitis. The patient’s vital signs are normal and he is started on broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and insulin. An hour later the patient’s heart rate increases to 125 beats per minute and the erythema has progressed to the thigh with new blister formation on the leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: CT scan of the right lower extremity

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate surgical intervention with incision and direct visualization of potentially infected tissue

questions.correct_answer: D. Immediate surgical intervention with incision and direct visualization of potentially infected tissue
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Immediate surgical intervention with incision and direct visualization of potentially infected tissue

questions.text: This is a schematic diagram depicting body structure of which of these helminthes?

Virat and Kishor were asked to demonstrate in dogs the role of sinus nerve in hypovolemic shock. Virat severed the sinus nerve when the mean blood pressure (MBP) was 85 mm Hg and Kishor cut the sinus nerve when the mean blood pressure was 55 mm Hg. On cutting the sinus nerve:

options.label: A
options.text: Virat recorded a decrease in MBP but Kishor recorded an increase in MBP

options.label: B
options.text: Virat recorded an increase in MBP but Kishor recorded a decrease in MBP

options.label: C
options.text: Virat and Kishor both recorded an increase in MBP

options.label: D
options.text: Virat and Kishor both recorded a decrease in MBP

questions.correct_answer: B. Virat recorded an increase in MBP but Kishor recorded a decrease in MBP
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Virat recorded an increase in MBP but Kishor recorded a decrease in MBP.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a complaint of a painful lump in her right groin that has been gradually increasing in size over the past few weeks. She describes the pain as constant and sharp, exacerbated when she coughs or strains. The patient has a history of multiple pregnancies and has noticed a bulge in her groin area when lifting heavy objects. On examination, there is a tender, firm, and irreducible mass in the right femoral region just below the inguinal ligament. The overlying skin appears erythematous. The patient's vital signs are stable. Proper diagnosis was made with all clinical examination and surgical treatment was decided. During this surgery it became very important to identify the pectineal ligament, lacunar ligament & inguinal ligament. Identify the ligaments in image?

options.label: A
options.text: A-Inguinal ligament, B-lacunar ligament, C-Pectineal ligament

options.label: B
options.text: A-Lacunar ligament, B-Inguinal ligament, C-Pectineal ligament

options.label: C
options.text: A-Pectineal ligament, B-Inguinal ligament, C-Lacunar ligament

options.label: D
options.text: A-Inguinal ligament, B-Pectineal ligament, C-Lacunar ligament

questions.correct_answer: D. A-Inguinal ligament, B-Pectineal ligament, C-Lacunar ligament
questions.explanation: Ans. D. A-Inguinal ligament, B-Pectineal ligament, C-Lacunar ligament

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presents to a psychiatrist two months after a tragic car accident in which his son died. He was driving the car with his son in the passenger seat at the time of the accident. Since then, he reports constant sadness, frequent crying spells, and inability to go to work. He also describes feeling extremely guilty and has been having thoughts of killing himself. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old child is brought to the clinic due to a history of recurrent infections, easy bruising, and persistent lymphadenopathy. The child's parents report that the lymph nodes have been enlarged for several months and are not painful. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated levels of double-negative T cells (CD3+, CD4-, CD8-) in the peripheral blood. The child has a history of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?

A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department with diplopia. Neurological examination reveals that he has difficulty in looking upward. On radiological examination a mass was found on dorsum of brain which was compressing the nearby structure. Which of the following statement is true in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Most probably this patient is presenting with tumour of B, which is causing compression of A; resulting in downward gaze.

options.label: B
options.text: Most probably this patient is presenting with tumour of C, which is causing compression of B; resulting in downward gaze.

options.label: C
options.text: Most probably this patient is presenting with tumour of B, which is causing compression of C; resulting in downward gaze.

options.label: D
options.text: Most probably this patient is presenting with tumour of A, which is causing compression of B; resulting in downward gaze.

questions.correct_answer: D. Most probably this patient is presenting with tumour of A, which is causing compression of B; resulting in downward gaze.
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Most probably this patient is presenting with tumour of A, which is causing compression of B; resulting in downward gaze.

questions.text: 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to an eye injury. The patient was helping his father to mow the lawn when a flying object struck his left eye. He has had foreign body sensation, pain, excessive tearing, and decreased vision in the eye. His father noticed noticed the eye being red but did not visualize any foreign objects. The patient has no other medical condtions and takes no medications. In the emergency department, the patient appears in obvious discomfort and keeps the left eye closed. Which of the following findings is most suggestive of globe perforation in this patient?

A 6-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent episodes of joint pain, swelling, and rash. The rash appears as erythematous, scaly plaques over the cheeks and buttocks. The child's parents mention that these symptoms seem to flare up periodically and are associated with fever. Physical examination reveals synovitis in multiple joints, and eye examination shows uveitis. Genetic testing is performed, revealing a mutation in the NOD2 gene. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?

An ENT Surgeon while doing singular neurectomy for intractable BPPV has cut its parent nerve accidentally. Which other structure is supposed to lose its sensory supply now, apart from posterior semicircular canal?

A postnatal day 2 weeks male infant Nanhe presented to his pediatrician Dr Anand with thrombocytopenia. Cardiopulmonary and abdomen examination showed no obvious abnormalities. However, his laboratory results were as follows: white blood cell 9000cells/ul, hemoglbin 15.2 g and platelet count around 50,000/ul. The immune function examination and blood lymphocyte subsets tests were mildly abnormal. The child died from brain bleeding shortly after admission. The family history documented that the infant’s uncle died in infancy due to repeated infections. His mother was physically healthy. A panel of gene mutation studies was performed and a loss of function mutation was detected in one of the genes. Which of the following genes is the most likely mutated in this child?

A 49-year-old woman is hospitalized with status epilepticus. Family members describe a 6-week history of agitation, delusions, hallucinations, and confusion. She is intubated and over the next 2 days continues to have intermittent seizures despite receiving lorazepam, fosphenytoin, and levetiracetam at maximal doses. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The patient is intubated; she is awake but does not follow commands. Neurologic examination otherwise has no focal abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies show a serum sodium level of 130 mEq/L (130 mmol/L), and the immunoassay result for the antibody to the leucine-rich glioma inactivated 1 subunit of the voltage-gated potassium channel is positive. Cerebrospinal fluid is normal, including a negative herpes simplex virus polymerase chain reaction result. MRI shows medial temporal lobe hyperintensity. Continuous electroencephalography reveals five seizures in the previous 24 hours, arising independently from both temporal lobes. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: Rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol plus dexamethasone

questions.text: A 49-year woman is undergoing a laparoscopic hysterectomy for adenomyosis. Her BMI is 34. Which is NOT used as a method to compensate for difficulties encountered in laparoscopy in an obese patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Steeper Trendelenburg to improve patients’ ventilation

options.label: B
options.text: Verres needle insertion at an angle perpendicular to the skin

options.label: C
options.text: Placement of additional ports to assist in lifting a fatter abdomen

options.label: D
options.text: Use of a gel pad and tucking of patients arms to prevent patient slippage

questions.correct_answer: A. Steeper Trendelenburg to improve patients’ ventilation

questions.text: A 23y G2 had atonic PPH during cesarean for placenta previa. A decision for internal iliac artery ligation is taken. What is the best place to ligate the internal iliac artery?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately after the bifurcation of the common iliac artery

options.label: B
options.text: Before the bifurcation of the common iliac artery

options.label: C
options.text: 3 cm after the bifurcation of the common iliac artery

options.label: D
options.text: Just before the posterior division is given off

questions.correct_answer: C. 3 cm after the bifurcation of the common iliac artery
questions.explanation: Ans. C. 3 cm after the bifurcation of the common iliac artery

questions.text: A teenage boy falls from his bicycle and is run over by a car. On arrival in the emergency room (ER), he is awake and alert and appears frightened but in no distress. The chest radiograph suggests an air-fluid level in the left lower lung field and the nasogastric tube seems to coil upward into the left chest. Which of the following is the next best step in his management?

options.label: A
options.text: Placement of a left intercostal drain tube in triangle of safety

questions.text: A 15 years old child with mental age 5 years will be classified as?
questions.correct_answer: C. Imbecile with Severe mental retardation
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Imbecile with Severe mental retardation

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after Iying on the floor in her home for the past 2 days. The patient's neighbor called police after phone calls were not answered and no one opened the door. She was found awake on the bathroom floor lying in feces and urine. The patient says she fell and injured her right hip and was unable to get up to call for help. She did not eat or drink anything during that time. On examination the patient appears dehydrated and has right hip tenderness. Laboratory studies show serum glucose of 72 mg/dL and positive urine ketones. Radiographs of the right hip show a right femoral neck fracture. Increased activity of which of the following enzymes is most likely contributing to both the serum and urine laboratory findings?

A 35-year-old male presents to the orthopaedic clinic with complaints of shoulder pain and weakness in his right arm for the past several weeks. He reports that the pain is most severe when he tries to lift objects or reach overhead. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the anterior aspect of the shoulder, and the patient demonstrates weakness in flexing his right arm against resistance. Which structure is having highest probability to affect in this case?

As a of a research study investigating enzymatic activity in both normal and diseased liver tissue, hepatocytes are isolated from biopsy samples obtained from patients undergoing routine care at a local tertiary referral center. The cells are homogenized and centrifuged to remove membrane components and organelles. Following subsequent rounds of centrifugation, the remaining supernatant contains only cytosol and cytosolic proteins. Activity of which of the following enzymes will most likely be detectable in the supernatant of healthy liver cells?

1-day-old boy is diagnosed with hyperphenylalanemia by newborn screening. He is placed on a special phenylalanine-restricted diet with tyrosine supplementation. The parents are extensively counselled on the boy's condition and informed of the necessary dietary restrictions. They are also instructed to return to his physician for regular follow-up visits. Several months later, laboratory test results indicate that the infant has a normal serum phenylalanine level. Careful examination, however, reveals some neurological abnormalities, including axial hypotonia and microcephaly. Further workup is notable for elevated prolactin. What is the likely deficiency leading to this presentation?

An 81-year-old man is evaluated during a follow-up visit after a recent hospitalization for new-onset heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. He initially presented with progressive shortness of breath and lower extremity edema. His symptoms were relieved by diuretic therapy and empagliflozin. ECG revealed normal sinus rhythm with low voltage. Transthoracic echocardiography showed a thickened left ventricular wall and an ejection fraction of 58%. Medical history includes COPD, hypertension, carpal tunnel syndrome, osteoarthritis, and localized prostate cancer. Medications include candesartan, empagliflozin, acetaminophen, torsemide, and tiotropium. On today's physical examination, blood pressure is 132/74 mm Hg, pulse rate is 82/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% with the patient breathing room air. There is no jugular venous distention, and the lung fields are clear. Cardiac examination reveals no murmur or extra heart sounds. There is no lower extremity edema. Results of serum and urine protein electrophoresis with immunofixation and free light-chain assay are normal. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging shows late gadolinium enhancement, suggesting amyloidosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A series of experiments are being conducted to determine the structure and function of different types of bacterial RNA. Cultures of Staphylococcus aureus are exposed to chemicals that lyse the bacterial cells, and the RNA molecules are then extracted. A specific RNA consisting of 90 nucleotides is purified for further analysis. It is found to contain high amounts of chemically modified bases such as dithydrouridine, pseudouridine, and its secondary structure arises from base pairing within the chain. Which of the following is the most likely composition of the 3'-end of this molecule?

34-year-old woman comes to the physician with abdominal pain and melena. She also complains of progressive fatigue and a 5 kg weight loss over the last 2 months. She has a strong family history of colon, endometrial, and ovarian cancer. Colonoscopy shows a protuberant, friable mass in the ascending colon, and biopsy is diagnostic for colon adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation consistent with Lynch syndrome. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the development of colon cancer in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Insertion of abnormal bases into DNA

questions.correct_answer: A. Nucleotide mismatches that escape repair

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for shortness of breath and chest discomfort of 2 days' duration. She has stage IV pancreatic cancer and recently completed a cycle of gemcitabine-based chemotherapy. Medical history is also relevant for hypertension, dyslipidemia, and hypothyroidism. Medications are lisinopril, atorvastatin, and levothyroxine. On physical examination, blood pressure is 144/76 mm Hg and pulse rate is 95/min. Oxygen saturation is 95% breathing ambient air. The examination is normal. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL (79.6 µmol/L); serum troponin and B-type natriuretic peptide levels are normal. CT scan of the chest shows several segmental pulmonary emboli without right ventricular dilation. An electrocardiogram is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?

options.label: C
options.text: IV Unfractionated Heparin followed by Warfarin

questions.text: 31-year-old woman comes to the office due to transient visual changes that are characterized by "loss of vision for a minute" and are commonly precipitated by bending forward or lifting objects. She has had persistent headaches over the last 3 months that she attributes to migraines. The patient takes over-the-counter analgesics as needed. Blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min and regular. BMI is 32.4 kg/m². Funduscopic examination of both eyes reveals the findings shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the observed funduscopic findings in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Impaired optic nerve axoplasmic flow
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Impaired optic nerve axoplasmic flow

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of skin tightness and sclerotic plaques on the lower trunk and left thigh. The plaques began with redness and induration. The skin tightness limits motion of the trunk. She reports no heartburn, Raynaud phenomenon, joint pain, or swelling. She has no other medical conditions and takes no medications. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There are indurated and sclerotic plaques on the trunk and one plaque on the left thigh, as shown. There is no sclerodactyly or telangiectasias. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

54-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to difficulty hearing for the past few weeks. During the neurologic examination, the physician assesses her hearing using a vibrating tuning fork. The handle of the tuning fork is placed on her left mastoid process until the sound is no longer audible. The tines are then quickly placed near the patient's left auditory meatus, and she reports hearing no sound. When the handle of the vibrating fork is placed on the middle of her forehead, she hears the vibration more strongly in her left ear than her right. This patient is most likely experiencing which of the following types of hearing loss?
questions.correct_answer: A. Conductive loss in left ear
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Conductive loss in left ear

questions.text: What is the likely cause of abdominal distension in this 55-year-old male?

An infant is born with facial dysmorphia and a cleft palate. Further evaluation reveals a heart condition with a right-to-left shunt and the absence of a thymic shadow on x-ray. The infant experiences frequent and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. Examination of this patient's lymph nodes will most likely show poor development of which of the following structures?

A 22-year-old previously healthy male presents to the emergency department with a five-day history of worsening symptoms. He initially complained of a sore throat and fever, which were managed with over-the-counter pain relievers. However, he now reports increasing difficulty swallowing and neck pain. On examination, the patient appears unwell, with a high fever (39.5°C or 103.1°F) and pronounced tenderness over the left side of his neck. His throat examination reveals severe pharyngitis with a swollen and erythematous uvula. Laboratory findings show leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the neck and chest is shown here. What is the most likely diagnosis?

14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to excessive urination and thirst. He has lost 4.5 kg (10 lb) in the last 3 weeks. The patient has no past medical problems. His father has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. Laboratory studies reveal blood glucose of 455 mg/dlL, normal anion gap, and hemoglobin A1c of 11.3%. The patient is diagnosed with type 1 diabetes, and treatment with insulin is initiated. ln addition to lowering blood glucose, insulin increases glycogen synthesis in hepatocytes. Activation of which of the following molecules most likely promotes this metabolic effect?

24-year-old woman comes to the office after discovering a new mole on her right leg. She is worried that it might be skin cancer as she has been going out in the sun very frequently because of her job as a reporter. Physical examination shows a 5-mm brown, oval macule on her anterior thigh with a homogeneous coloration and discrete borders. The lesion appears darker than her other moles. A biopsy of the lesion shows normal-appearing nevus cells clustered in the epidermis, and she is diagnosed with a benign acquired melanocytic nevus. During histologic analysis, her epithelial cells are each found to contain a condensed body composed of heavily methylated DNA at the periphery of the nucleus. This region of DNA is most likely associated with which of the following genetic findings?

6-year-old boy is brought to the office due to a persistent facial ulcer for the past 2 months. His mother reports that the patient has extreme sensitivity to sunlight and has developed freckles on his face, neck, and limbs since infancy. On physical examination, the skin in sun-exposed areas is dry and rough with numerous freckles and erythematous macules. There is an ulcerated plaque on the left face; a biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinoma. Further testing leads to a diagnosis of xeroderma pigmentosum. A defect in which of the following enzymes is most likely causing this patient's condition?
How excited are you for Cerebel-Hum?

options.label: C
options.text: Best part is meeting the mentors and faculty

questions.text: A 66-year-old man undergoes a low anterior resection for rectal adenocarcinoma. On the fifth day in hospital, his physical examination shows a temperature of 39°C (102°F), blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg, pulse of 110 beats per minute and regular, and respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen reveals an abscess in the pelvis. Which of the following most accurately describes his present condition?
Which of the following description best fits cholesteatoma?

options.label: A
options.text: A cholesterol containing tumour in the middle ear

options.label: B
options.text: Ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by endodermal derivative

options.label: C
options.text: Endodermal derivative in a space enclosed by ectodermal derivative

options.label: D
options.text: Mesodermal tissue proliferation in middle ear

questions.correct_answer: B. Ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by endodermal derivative
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by endodermal derivative

questions.text: 63-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine preventive examination. She has no significant medical problems and takes no medications. The patient consumes a balanced diet; gets regular exercise; and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or ilicit drugs. She is up to date on breast, colon, cervical, and lipid screenings. Her physical examination findings are unremarkable. The patient expresses concern about wrinkles around her eyes that make her "look old." A decrease in which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's complaint?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the paediatrician by her parents due to a rapidly spreading skin rash. On examination, there are widespread areas of erythema with large areas of skin exfoliation as shown below. The parents report that the child had a recent episode of sore throat for which they did not seek medical attention. On further workup, cultures from the skin lesions grow Staphylococcus aureus. The pathogenesis of this child's skin condition is most similar to which of the following diseases?

Dr. Amrit Nasta is consulted regarding a 56-year-old patient, Alok, who has been diagnosed with metastatic melanoma. Alok's pathology report indicates a high expression of PD-L1 in tumor cells. After previously showing resistance to the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib, Dr. Nasta decides to administer pembrolizumab, an immune checkpoint inhibitor, hoping to harness Alok's immune system against the tumor. A week into treatment with pembrolizumab, Alok presents with fatigue, joint pain, a mild rash, and an elevation of liver enzymes in his blood tests. What is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
In which of the following study designs, the Outcome of interest has already taken place when the study is started?

An elderly patient is admitted to the hospital with a severe case of polio that has affected their respiratory muscles. Despite maximal medical therapy, the patient is experiencing significant respiratory distress and requires mechanical ventilation. Due to the patient's unique needs, the medical team decides to use an iron lung for respiratory support. Which of the following best describes the functioning principle of above given support system and its application in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: The iron lung uses positive pressure to assist with inhalation and exhalation, enhancing oxygenation and CO2 removal.

options.label: B
options.text: The iron lung relies on negative pressure to create a vacuum around the patient's chest, promoting lung expansion and gas exchange.

options.label: C
options.text: The iron lung is equipped with advanced ventilator algorithms and real-time monitoring to adjust ventilation parameters automatically.

options.label: D
options.text: The iron lung stimulates the phrenic nerve through electrical impulses, restoring normal diaphragmatic function.

questions.correct_answer: B. The iron lung relies on negative pressure to create a vacuum around the patient's chest, promoting lung expansion and gas exchange.
questions.explanation: Ans. B. The iron lung relies on negative pressure to create a vacuum around the patient's chest, promoting lung expansion and gas exchange.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is undergoing spinal surgery for the correction of severe thoracic kyphosis. The surgical team is particularly concerned about potential damage to the spinal cord during the procedure. In order to continuously assess the integrity of specific neural pathways, the anaesthesiologist and neurologist decide to use intraoperative monitoring. Which of the following intraoperative monitoring techniques provides real-time information about the functional status of motor pathways, and is most appropriate for detecting early signs of spinal cord ischemia?

A 35-year-old doctor is evaluated for a needlestick injury that occurred earlier in the day while she was at work. She received the hepatitis B vaccination series 5 years ago and checked her anti-HBS titer which was > 10 mU/mL. The source patient has known active hepatitis B infection. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Apart from a tiny puncture wound at the site of injury, the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient's hepatitis B exposure?

options.label: B
options.text: Hepatitis B surface antigen and hepatitis B core antibody testing in 6 months

questions.text: A Pregnant woman in third trimester complains of hearing her own sounds. Examination of the ear shows movements of tympanic membrane synchronous with respiration and especially exaggerated when nostril on the contralateral side is occluded. Your diagnosis is:

A woman has just had her dating ultrasound scan done. The sonographer has clearly documented two gestational sacs (T-sign) and conformed 10 weeks MCDA viable twins. The woman asks you for further information about MCDA twins. Which of the following statements will you quote in your counselling?

options.label: A
options.text: A special fetal echocardiographic assessment should be done routinely in MCDA twin pregnancies

options.label: B
options.text: MCDA twins are 1% of all pregnancies

options.label: C
options.text: MCDA twins has a 15% chance of developing twin to twin transfusion syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: She may require an extra scan at around 15 weeks as chorionicity is best established after 14 weeks.

questions.correct_answer: C. MCDA twins has a 15% chance of developing twin to twin transfusion syndrome
questions.explanation: Ans. C. MCDA twins has a 15% chance of developing twin to twin transfusion syndrome

questions.text: A 26y old primigravida who is also a school teacher, was exposed to chicken pox 7 days ago. She is currently 19 weeks pregnant. She does not remember getting a chickenpox rash in childhood. Serum testing for varicella was done and was found to be non-immune to varicella. What is the single best advice for her?

options.label: A
options.text: VZIG will not be effective this late after exposure

options.label: C
options.text: Treat as infectious up to 28 days

options.label: D
options.text: Check for features of fetal varicella syndrome on 20 weeks scan

questions.text: If the plasma concentration of a freely filterable substance is 2 mg/mL, GFR is 100 mL/min, urine concentration of the substance is 10 mg/mL, and urine flow rate is 5 mL/min, we can conclude that the kidney tubules:

A 30-year-old woman presents to her obstetrician for a routine prenatal check-up during her first trimester of pregnancy. She is eager to learn about the development of her growing fetus and asks about the early stages of spinal cord formation. The obstetrician explains that during the early 6th week of embryonic life, significant developmental events occur in the cervical region of the spinal cord. These events involve the notochord, a critical structure in embryonic development. Identify the position of the different structures in the image below?

options.label: A
options.text: A - dorsal root ganglion, B – dorsal root of spinal nerve, C – notochord, D – trunk of spinal nerve.

options.label: B
options.text: A - ventral root of spinal nerve, B – dorsal root ganglion, C – notochord, D – trunk of spinal nerve.

options.label: C
options.text: A - ventral root of spinal nerve, B – dorsal root of spinal nerve, C – notochord, D – trunk of spinal nerve.

options.label: D
options.text: A - dorsal root of spinal nerve, B – ventral root of spinal nerve, C – notochord, D – trunk of spinal nerve.

questions.correct_answer: D. A - dorsal root of spinal nerve, B – ventral root of spinal nerve, C – notochord, D – trunk of spinal nerve.
questions.explanation: Ans. D. A - dorsal root of spinal nerve, B – ventral root of spinal nerve, C – notochord, D – trunk of spinal nerve.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought in to the physician’s office with a 3-day history of fever and a rash. He has also had a mild sore throat and felt somewhat fatigued. His mother is concerned that he could have “scarlet fever.” The rash started on his face and then spread to his arms and legs. He has only been given acetaminophen for the fever. He takes no other medications, has no known allergies, has no significant medical history, and has had no contact with anyone known to be ill. On examination, his temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), and his other vital signs are normal. His cheeks are notably red, almost as if they had been slapped. His pharynx is normal appearing, and the remainder of his head and neck exam is normal. On his extremities there is a fine, erythematous, maculopapular rash but no vesicles or petechiae. A rapid group A streptococcal antigen test done in the office is negative. Identify the organism likely cause of this illness and tell in which human cells does this virus cause lytic infections?
In each scenario, choose the best plan for management:

Dr. Sparsh Gupta is conducting a clinical study involving a 30-year-old participant named Kunal. They are examining a novel, pharmacologically inert substance called Y to study its elimination kinetics. Previous trials have shown that Y follows first order kinetics and has the plasma half-life of 1 hour. During the initial stage of the clinical trial, Kunal receives an intravenous administration of Y at a concentration of 20 mg/mL, infused at a constant rate of 2 mL/min for 12 hours. After ensuring that Y has been completely eliminated from Kunal's system, Dr. Gupta introduces changes to the protocol for a subsequent phase. The concentration of the solution is adjusted to 30 mg/mL, and the infusion rate is increased to 3 mL/min. Given the modifications to the infusion method, which among the following pharmacokinetic parameters related to Y is expected to change?

options.label: C
options.text: Time required to reach the steady-state concentration

questions.explanation: Ans. B. Steady state plasma concentration attained

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is evaluated at a follow-up visit. Two days ago, she was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and started on trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She has mild dysuria but is otherwise asymptomatic. Medical history is significant for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, chronic kidney disease, and hypertension. Other medications are atorvastatin and enalapril, which she has been taking for 5 years. Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are unremarkable. Laboratory studies performed 3 months ago showed a blood urea nitrogen level of 20 mg/dL (7.1 mmol/L) and a serum creatinine level of 1.3 mg/dL (115 µmol/L). Today's laboratory studies: Hemoglobin A1c 6.0 % Blood urea nitrogen 19 mg/dL (6.8 mmol/L) Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL (141.4 µmol/L) Urinalysis No blood, protein, or erythrocytes Urine albumin-creatinine ratio <30 mg/g Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A 40-year-old man presents with concerns about changes in his nails, which have persisted for several years. The nails show onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed) and pitting. He recalls receiving treatment with terbinafine from an outside physician with no relief. On closer examination, you notice well-demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales on his elbows and knees. Additionally, he reports morning shoulder stiffness and back pain that lasts 1-2 hours but tends to improve with activity. Which of the following is true regarding his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: 50% of patients present with joint disease prior to skin involvement

options.label: B
options.text: Bony erosions are not commonly seen on radiographs

options.label: C
options.text: J oint disease correlates with severity of skin involvement

questions.correct_answer: D. Rheumatoid factor is commonly absent
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Rheumatoid factor is commonly absent

questions.text: A 23-year-old, previously healthy man presents to the ER after sustaining a single gunshot wound to the left chest. The entrance wound is 3 cm inferior to the nipple and the exit wound is just below the scapula. A chest tube is placed that drains 400 mL of blood and continues to drain 50 to 75 mL/h during the initial resuscitation. Initial blood pressure of 70/0 mm Hg has responded to 2-L crystalloid and is now 100/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Chest x-ray reveals a re-expanded lung and no free air under the diaphragm. Which of the following is the best next step in his management?

A 20-year-old male presents to the orthopedic clinic with a chief complaint of recurrent and painful swellings in various muscle groups. He reports that these episodes have been occurring since childhood, with the first episode observed around the age of 5. On examination, you note palpable, firm, and immobile masses within the muscles of his upper arms, thighs, and back. The patient's range of motion in these affected muscle groups is significantly restricted. The skeletal survey of the patient is shown here. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this patient's clinical presentation?

A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) presents with worsening fatigue and lymphocytosis. Dr Sparsh performed his flow cytometry of peripheral blood which reveals an increased number of CD19+CD5+ B lymphocytes. What is the most likely interpretation of this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Disease progression to acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)

options.label: D
options.text: Normal variation in CLL cell surface markers

questions.text: Incorrect combination about Contraceptive composition is?

options.label: A
options.text: Mala N: Ethinyl estradiol 0.03 mcg, Levonorgestrel 0.15 mcg

questions.correct_answer: A. Mala N: Ethinyl estradiol 0.03 mcg, Levonorgestrel 0.15 mcg

questions.text: Dr. Vivek Jain is reviewing medications at a community health camp. One of his tasks is to counsel on the effective use of glipizide for managing elevated blood sugar levels. Among the attendees, there's a diverse group of patients with various health profiles. Dr. Jain recognizes that glipizide can reduce blood sugar in many patient groups, but there's one category of individuals in which it might not have a notable effect. Which of the following patients is LEAST likely to experience a significant reduction in blood sugar levels with glipizide?

options.label: B
options.text: A 45 year old obese person with type 2 diabetes mellitus

options.label: C
options.text: A 50-year-old woman with Polycystic Ovary Disease and impaired glucose tolerance.

questions.correct_answer: D. A 65-year-old man with type 1 diabetes.
questions.explanation: Ans. D. A 65-year-old man with type 1 diabetes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man who lives in downtown Philadelphia presents to his physician with a 4-day history of terrible headache, fever, and stiff neck. He has always been in good health and attributes this to his healthy eating habits and his daily running through the city parks near his apartment. The physician suspects the man may have cryptococcal meningitis and collects CSF for examination. Which of the following results would you most likely expect from this patient’s CSF studies?

options.label: A
options.text: Elevated CSF pressure with increased white cell counts

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated polymorphonuclear cells with high protein levels

options.label: C
options.text: Elevated lymphocytes with normal glucose levels

options.label: D
options.text: Normal CSF pressure with a positive Gram stain reaction

questions.correct_answer: A. Elevated CSF pressure with increased white cell counts
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Elevated CSF pressure with increased white cell counts

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a 6-mm basal cell carcinoma on the tip of his nose. He is scheduled to undergo excision of the tumor in the operating room with repair of the defect using skin and subcutaneous tissue from his earlobe. Which of the following terms most appropriately describes this form of reconstructive surgery?

A 55-year-old female with a history of major depressive disorder and peptic ulcer disease is currently managed on both antidepressant and anti-ulcer therapies. She presents to the clinic with tremors, confusion, and agitation. The physician suspects an unintended drug interaction. Which combination of antidepressant and anti-ulcer medication is most likely responsible for her presentation?

A 55-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath. The patient's arterial blood gases reveal a low partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) and a high partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2). The healthcare team decides to initiate mechanical ventilation to provide respiratory support. Which of the following best explains the phenomenon of "auto-PEEP" that can occur in patients with severe COPD during mechanical ventilation?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased intrapulmonary shunting leading to ventilation-perfusion mismatch.

options.label: B
options.text: Insufficient tidal volume delivery causing alveolar collapse and reduced gas exchange.

options.label: C
options.text: Positive pressure ventilation causing air trapping and dynamic hyperinflation.

options.label: D
options.text: Impaired surfactant production resulting in decreased lung compliance.

questions.correct_answer: C. Positive pressure ventilation causing air trapping and dynamic hyperinflation.
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Positive pressure ventilation causing air trapping and dynamic hyperinflation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man whose father was just diagnosed with colon cancer presents to his family physician to discuss screening colonoscopy. His physician suspects that he has hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) or Lynch syndrome and recommends screening colonoscopy beginning at age 25. Which of the following is most supportive of a clinical diagnosis of HNPCC?

options.label: A
options.text: A father and an uncle (same side of the family) with colon cancer

options.label: B
options.text: A father and grandfather (same side of the family) with colon cancer

options.label: C
options.text: A father and 2 uncles (same side of the family) with colon cancer

options.label: D
options.text: A father, uncle, and grandfather (same side of the family) with colon cancer at 50 years of age

questions.correct_answer: D. A father, uncle, and grandfather (same side of the family) with colon cancer at 50 years of age

questions.text: A patient while eating fish felt something suddenly stuck in her throat and came to ER. She is having a pricky sensation in her throat. She was advised an X-ray which is given below. Find the location of foreign body.

A 76-year-old man is evaluated for painless lymphadenopathy of several months' duration. He has no other symptoms. Infectious work-up was negative, and the lymphadenopathy did not improve. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he takes no medications. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There are multiple rubbery lymph nodes in bilateral cervical, inguinal, and axillary areas varying in size from 1 to 3 cm. There is no hepatomegaly or splenomegaly. Results of complete blood count, comprehensive chemistry profile, HIV testing, and measurement of lactate dehydrogenase level are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to perform next?

options.label: A
options.text: CT of the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis

options.label: B
options.text: Excisional biopsy of a cervical lymph node

options.label: C
options.text: Fine-needle aspiration of a cervical lymph node

options.label: D
options.text: PET/CT of the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.correct_answer: B. Excisional biopsy of a cervical lymph node

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of previous right thyroidectomy for a benign thyroid nodule now undergoes completion thyroidectomy for a suspicious thyroid mass. Several hours postoperatively, she develops progressive swelling under the incision, stridor, and difficulty breathing. Orotracheal intubation is successful. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Fiberoptic laryngoscopy to rule out bilateral vocal cord paralysis

options.label: C
options.text: Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and debridement of the wound

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman notices a persistent, painless lump in the left breast. On examination the left breast has a single mobile mass without evidence of skin changes or lymphadenopathy in the neck or axilla. An ultrasound demonstrates a solid, 1-cm mass in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. A core-needle biopsy shows invasive ductal carcinoma. The patient is in her first trimester of pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Termination of the pregnancy followed by modified radical mastectomy

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate administration of chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy after delivery of the baby

options.label: C
options.text: Breast conservation therapy in third trimester

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is evaluated for anemia discovered during a preoperative assessment for total hip arthroplasty. She has no other medical problems and has no symptoms other than hip pain. Her only medication is paracetamol. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Restricted range of motion of the left hip is noted. Laboratory studies: Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL Leukocyte count 5000/µL MCV 70 fL Platelet count 600,000/µL Reticulocyte count 1% Ferritin 12 ng/mL Peripheral smear: microcytosis and anisopoikilocytosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

A 45-year-old man was discovered to have a hepatic flexure colon cancer during a colonoscopy for anemia requiring transfusions. Upon exploration of his abdomen in the operating room, an unexpected discontinuous 3-cm metastasis is discovered in the edge of the right lobe of the liver. Preoperatively, the patient was counseled of this possibility and the surgical options. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Right hemicolectomy with local resection of the liver metastasis

options.label: C
options.text: Closure of the abdomen followed by chemotherapy

options.label: D
options.text: Right hemicolectomy with postoperative radiation therapy to the liver

questions.correct_answer: B. Right hemicolectomy with local resection of the liver metastasis

questions.text: 65-year-old male complains of bilateral visual difficulty that has progressed over the last year. Funduscopy reveals small yellow retinal lesions clustered in the macula. Which of the following would you expect most on visual field examination?

A 30-day-old female baby, born at full-term, to nonconsanguinous parents, presented with a history of feeding difficulty and failure to thrive. There was a history of respiratory distress and cyanosis at birth. What is the likely diagnosis?
What is the likely clinical complaint of this patient?

A 26-year-old man develops dysuria and purulent urethral discharge following unprotected sex with a new partner. Nucleic acid amplification testing is positive for Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. The patient develops antibody against the bacterial pili that enhance attachment to host cells. His symptoms resolve with adequate treatment. His partner does not receive treatment. Several weeks later, the patient develops N gonorrhoeae reinfection after repeat exposure to the same partner. Which of the following is the most likely reason for the lack of long-lasting immunity against the bacteria despite antibody formation in this patient?

24-year-old female presents to your office with burning urination, urgency, and frequency. She is sexually active. Urine cultures show catalase-positive, gram-positive cocci. The organism responsible for this patient's symptoms is most likely to be:

55-year-old man with end-stage hepatitis C virus infection undergoes orthotopic liver transplantation from a deceased donor. The patient has no perioperative complications and is discharged from the hospital on appropriate immunosuppressant medications. One week after the surgery, he develops nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea. Physical examination shows a painful maculopapular rash over his neck, back and extremities that extends to the palms and soles. Endoscopic evaluation reveals multiple ulcerations of the intestinal mucosa. Which of the following is he most likely cause of this patient's current condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Graft B cell sensitization against host MHC antigens

options.label: B
options.text: Graft T cell sensitization against host MHC antigens

options.label: C
options.text: Host B cell sensitization against graft MHC antigens

options.label: D
options.text: Host T cell sensitization against graft MHC antigens

questions.correct_answer: B. Graft T cell sensitization against host MHC antigens
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Graft T cell sensitization against host MHC antigens

questions.text: 33-year-old female is being followed by her neurologist for her multiple sclerosis. She was initially diagnosed with relapsing remitting subtype after an episode of visual disturbance and an episode of paralysis. in her study of autoimmune diseases she encounters the topic of lymphocyte development and comes across a question which she poses to her neurologist during a routine follow-up visit: During the process of T-lymphocyte maturation, T cell receptors of many lymphocytes demonstrate a very high-affinity interaction with MHC molecules expressed on thymic medullary epithelial and dendritic cells. What process do these lymphocytes undergo at this time?

A healthy couple, who recently emigrated from Eastern Europe, bring their 3-year-old son to the office for evaluation of an eczematous rash. On examination, the child also shows signs of intellectual disability and gait abnormality and has a musty body odor. What is the likelihood that this couple's next child will be affected with the same disease?

26-year-old woman is being evaluated for a possible inherited disorder. She has a 6-year history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and a year ago, she had partial loss of vision due to an occipital infarction. Her mother has chronic intermittent muscle weakness and lactic acidosis and her maternal uncle has hemiplegia. Skeletal muscle biopsy of the patient shows ragged-appearing muscle fibers. After further evaluation, all the affected family members are found to suffer from the same inherited disease. Pedigree analysis is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the variability of clinical manifestations in the affected family members?

A 50-year-old male presents with abdominal pain, nausea, and a palpable mass in the abdomen. Dr Zainab did his imaging which reveals a well-circumscribed, heterogeneously enhancing mass arising from the muscular wall of the stomach. She suggested a biopsy of the mass. Dr Sparsh reported bland spindle cells with faintly eosinophilic cytoplasm in a syncytial pattern; and elongated nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 47-year-old male presents to his primary care physician Dr Dileep with complaints of fatigue, easy bruising, and night sweats. On physical examination, splenomegaly is noted. He is referred to Cerebellum Pathology Lab where the complete blood count reveals an elevated white blood cell count with a left shift, increased basophils, and increased myeloid cells. She reports sudden onset of worsening symptoms for last 5 days. Which of the following is a criterion for the diagnosis of accelerated phase of chronic myeloid leukemia according to WHO 2017 criteria?

options.label: A
options.text: 5 - 10% blasts in bone marrow or peripheral blood

options.label: B
options.text: Persistent platelet count < 100,000 related to therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Additional clonal chromosomal abnormalities like second Ph chromosome, trisomy 8, isochromosome 17q

questions.correct_answer: D. Additional clonal chromosomal abnormalities like second Ph chromosome, trisomy 8, isochromosome 17q

questions.text: A 48-year-old female patient presented with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain, which is often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals multiple peptic ulcers in the duodenal bulb. Laboratory tests show elevated gastrin levels. She was given Prilosec for a long time. She was also consuming a vegetarian diet and now presented with tiredness & palpitations since a month. She complained of progressive sensory loss in her lower extremities. Neurological examination reveals impaired vibratory sensation in both legs. An MRI of the spinal cord shows no structural abnormalities. On blood examination she had following haematological slide was found. All of the following statements are correct in this case except:

options.label: A
options.text: This is a case of gastrinoma with high gastrin secretion resulting in hypersecretion of hydrochloric acid.

options.label: B
options.text: Prilosec is an example of a proton pump inhibitor which may cause decrease Vit B12 absorption.

options.label: C
options.text: In this patient due to Vitamin B 12 deficiency myelination of anterior spinothalamic tract has been affected.

options.label: D
options.text: On haematological examination Increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV, >100 fL) and mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) and polymorphonuclear cells with multiple lobes are found.

questions.correct_answer: C. In this patient due to Vitamin B 12 deficiency myelination of anterior spinothalamic tract has been affected.
questions.explanation: Ans. C. In this patient due to Vitamin B 12 deficiency myelination of anterior spinothalamic tract has been affected.

questions.text: 4-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for a routine health maintenance visit. The patient has been toilet trained for 2 years. He sees a pediatric dentist every 6 months and has no dental caries. The boy's mother describes him as a picky eater. She states that he prefers to eat bananas, apples, and bread but dislikes vegetables, meat, and milk products. He participates in a weekly community soccer league. He had acute gastroenteritis twice during infancy, but has no chronic medical conditions and takes no medications. The boy lives with his mother, who is a single parent, and 2 older brothers. He attends preschool 5 days per week and is learning to write his name. His mother says that he is not a social child and prefers to play with his best friend or his brothers. Which of the following preventive health measures is most appropriate at this visit?
ICT enabled Adherence System under National TB Elimination program is:
